JOHNS HOPKINS MEN IN THE WEST.
LAWRENCE, KANSAS, JANUARY 2nd, 1902.
To the Aditor of"THE NEWS-LETTER":—
accordance with your request to write a few lines concerning the influence of Hopkins men in the West, I have the pleasure to respond as follows,
concerning a territory which might be called the Southwest in distinction from
the northern tier of western states. This would include Iowa, Nebraska, Missouri, Kansas, Arkansas, Texas, and Oklahoma.
To my knowledge there are over seventy alumni and ex-students of the
Johns Hopkins University within this territory engaged in professional work.
Of these I find seven in the University of Kansas, eight in the University of
Missouri, five in the University of Arkansas, three in the University of Iowa,
and seven in the University of Nebraska. The remainder are scattered in the
various universities and colleges of the Southwest.
I need not say to you that this large body of men, going forth well equipped with Johns Hopkins instruction and methods, and moreover partaking of
the Johns Hopkins spirit of making the truth subservient to the good of
humanity, has great influence on the educational work in their respective
institutions.
Compared with Eastern institutions of greater age or more wealthy foundations the Western institutions are lacking in equipment. Also, notwithstanding
the progressive spirit of the West, there is always a lack in the organized support of higher culture and learning. In the making of the West, so-called
practical ideas predominate, and there is a tendency to make education immediately serviceable to material prosperity; and hence, the educational spirit
Which surrounds the Western institution varies somewhat from that surrounding an Eastern institution where culture has been the predominant feature.
The Johns Hopkins men have found it necessary to adapt themselves to
circumstances, and while they love the truth for the truth's sake, their greater
work has been the adaptation of this truth to the uplifting of humanity and the
education of the people in right thinking. Perhaps every university man is, in
one sense, a missionary of the truth, and this seems more apparent in the West
than in the East. The University man in the West is supposed to know almost
everything, and is called upon to lecture on all sorts of subjects pertaining to
the political, social, economic, or scientific life of the people. Under such cirIn

cumstances special investigation and profound research are difficult, and, in
most cases, I may say, impossible. Libraries are small; the hours of school
service in the university are long; the requirements for outside lectures are
great, so that while a Western professor may be able to do some fairly good
work in his attempt to add to the "sum of human knowledge," his chief work
is that of instructor both within and without the university.
The great West is absorbing. In the attempt to develop its resources millions of capital are taken up, much of it never to be returned. It is so in educational affairs. The university and the community demand the professor's
time, his ideas, indeed, his whole life. They take all he has to give just as a
sponge takes water, except that they never reach a point of saturation. I have
this therefore to say of the Johns Hopkins men in the West, that, while probably few of them will put on record any great literary or scientific achievements,
their services will be best noted in the general improvement of the communitks
in which they live and the advancement of the educational institution to which
they are attached.
Under such circumstances it would be impossible to make any definite
estimate of their services in the cause of education or their influences upon
humanity, for much that they do will be shown in the higher educational ideals
and a better social and political life of the community, to be revealed more
especially in the future than in the present, a general good which is traced to
no one in particular.
As it is, the professor in wealthy Eastern institutions, called upon for a
few lectures each week, surrounded by magnificent libraries and finely equipped
laboratories, with comfortable salaries, in close touch with learned societies and
easy access of European learning, may establish lines of culture, write learned
books giving forth new discoveries; but the Western professor must be content
to serve his community though it absorbs his very life, counting it fortunate to
read the results of the research of his more favored brethren in the East, and
conscious that his services are exhibited in the youth he h As helped forward and
the community he has served.

FRANK W. BLACKMAR,
Ex-President Johns Hopkins Club of the Middle West.

THE QUARTER-CENTENNIAL CELEBRATION.
ORK is being actively pushed for the two days exercises on February 2122, which are to commemorate the twenty-fifth anniversary of the opening of work at the Hopkins, and which will also formally inaugurate
President Remsen. Dr, Gilman, President Emeritus of the University, will have
charge on the first day, and will deliver an address, to be followed by responses
from visiting delegates. On the second day, President Remsen will be inaugurated, and will take charge of the ceremonies, which are to include the conferring of honorary degrees. This is quite a departure from the traditional policy

THE CHRISTMAS TRIP OF THE MUSICAL CLUBS.
N the dawn of December 26, the members of the Musical Clubs, rubbing
their eyes and joking about being up so early in the morning, left Camden
Station on a special car for West Virginia. Their first concert was given
that night at Charlestown. While the whole programme was well appreciated,
the banjo solo by V. B. Smith, and "Dixie" by the Glee Club, were most
loudly applauded. After the concert, the men were invited to several small entertainments given to them by some of the residents of the town.
When the clubs were on the point of leaving Charlestown the next morning,
a great excitement arose. "Where is Ham, Jr.?" Sure enough the club's
mascot had suddenly disappeared. After considerable searching, he was found,
with his mouth wide open with astonishment, gazing at the "funny" eggshaped heads of the local "crowd."
The second concert was at Winchester, which has always been noted for
the kind reception that she gives Hopkins boys. This year, an audience, even
larger than that of last year, turned out to hear them in the theatre of the new
town hall, built by Charles Broadway Rouss. If the success of the concert could
be measured by the applause, it was immense. The dance given to the club
after the concert by the youth and beauty of Winchester was greatly enjoyed.
The next morning the men hired vehicles, and took their lady friends out driving. But, alas, 2.10 came too soon, and the hard-hearted manager hurried them
off to Hagerstown. Many and touching were the good-byes on leaving Winchester, and the men all declared that it was the place where they wanted to go
when they died.
.
This year, the clubs went from Winchester to Hagerstown by a different
and more rapid route, over the Cumberland Valley Railroad, through the beautiful Shenandoah Valley. At Hagerstown, the audience was small. Although
this was on account of the rain, it is probable that the clubs will not return
there for several years. After the concert, the last dance was given to the
club; it was well arranged and very enjoyable.
The programmes for all the concerts were creditably rendered. The Banjo
Club was undoubtedly the best. Its pieces, though few, were well chosen and
well played. The Glee Club was a close second, though not because it had a
large number of pieces. The Mandolin Club did not seem to be up to the high
standard of last year.
While the trip this year was greatly enjoyed it differed materially from
former ones. Of the various "clubs" that sprung up and added to the general
enjoyment, the "Goonay" was the only survivor of last year. Then, too, the
mysterious flitting around of Andrew Reid Bird was greatly missed, although
his place, as manager, was admirably filled by Robinson Cator Pagon,'03.

HE first twenty-five years in the growth of anything, be it man or institution, are always the most vital, the most fraught with dangers, and the
most full of obstacles; and when these years are successfully passed
there is always just cause for a halt and a retrospect. The Johns Hopkins
University will, on February 2122, stop its regular routine for a celebration of
a quarter of a century's growth, which in methods and results has filled educators in Europe and America with wonder. The founding of the University
marked an epoch in education in the United States, for methods entirely unknown on this side of the Atlantic were introduced into the Hopkins system of
instruction. The exceedingly high standard of the great German universities
were set as the goal for the Hopkins graduate departments, so that now the
reputation of the Hopkins degree of philosophy surpasses that of any American
University, and equals the best in Europe. A recent account published in the
daily papers of this country from an interview with a Yale graduate, stated
that though Yale, old as she is, was seldom mentioned in European educational
circles, the name of Johns Hopkins bore a magic charm; while in America any
graduate from the "phiolosophical machine" of Hopkins, a name by which the
University was once characterized, can secure a teaching position anywhere.
Results such as these, attained in so short a period as twenty-five years, are
surely worthy of a great celebration, especially as this year we stand on the
threshhold of a new era, and begin the second quarter under a new president
whose inauguration occurs at the same time. It is true that owing to a remarkable lack of support, the dawn of the new era is not as bright as it should be;
yet it seems that it must almost be a result of a natural phenomenon for the
clouds to clear, for the alumni and friends of the University to recognize that
what it has done it can continue to do—if nobly supported by those it has
reared, and by those to whom it has brought an untold wealth.

The only correct paper submitted at the Christmas examination in Public Speaking.

EADING aloud is a graceful accomplishment possessed by comparatively
few. Too often the home reading is Fpoiled by a dreary monotone that
the reader does not strive to overcome. If the patient listeners would
only strive to overcome the possesser of the dreary monotone the fault might,
in time, be remedied. How much brighter would home become if we took care
to read correctly! Even papa would take a livelier interest in the reading of
the stockmarket reports if only his silvery-tongued daughter would read the
records to him. In time a great improvement and growth would be seen in the
family (not in size hut in interest.) Little Johnnie would no longer take
pleasure in reading about Diamond Dick in the woodshed; coming under the
benign influence of the home reading circle he would gradually be elevated until he could read with pleasure, if not with profit, the Fables of George Ade, and
the war poems of Rudyard Kipling.
DIRECTIONS: Grab the book, paper, or pamphlet, in the left hand, hold it
to the side, slightly below the face, and about eighteen inches from the head.

naturally. By naturally I do not mean that the elocutionary tyro should shout
Hamlet's Address to the Players, nor declaim in funeral tones the Charge of
the Light Brigade. The neophyte in the realms of oratorical art should strive
to acquire a becoming elocution through carefully, painstakingly, laboriously

JOHNS HOPKINS MEN IN THE WEST.
LAWRENCE, KANSAS, JANUARY 2nd, 1902.
To the Aditor of"THE NEWS-LETTER":—
accordance with your request to write a few lines concerning the influence of Hopkins men in the West, I have the pleasure to respond as follows,
concerning a territory which might be called the Southwest in distinction from
the northern tier of western states. This would include Iowa, Nebraska, Missouri, Kansas, Arkansas, Texas, and Oklahoma.
To my knowledge there are over seventy alumni and ex-students of the
Johns Hopkins University within this territory engaged in professional work.
Of these I find seven in the University of Kansas, eight in the University of
Missouri, five in the University of Arkansas, three in the University of Iowa,
and seven in the University of Nebraska. The remainder are scattered in the
various universities and colleges of the Southwest.
I need not say to you that this large body of men, going forth well equipped with Johns Hopkins instruction and methods, and moreover partaking of
the Johns Hopkins spirit of making the truth subservient to the good of
humanity, has great influence on the educational work in their respective
institutions.
Compared with Eastern institutions of greater age or more wealthy foundations the Western institutions are lacking in equipment. Also, notwithstanding
the progressive spirit of the West, there is always a lack in the organized support of higher culture and learning. In the making of the West, so-called
practical ideas predominate, and there is a tendency to make education immediately serviceable to material prosperity; and hence, the educational spirit
Which surrounds the Western institution varies somewhat from that surrounding an Eastern institution where culture has been the predominant feature.
The Johns Hopkins men have found it necessary to adapt themselves to
circumstances, and while they love the truth for the truth's sake, their greater
work has been the adaptation of this truth to the uplifting of humanity and the
education of the people in right thinking. Perhaps every university man is, in
one sense, a missionary of the truth, and this seems more apparent in the West
than in the East. The University man in the West is supposed to know almost
everything, and is called upon to lecture on all sorts of subjects pertaining to
the political, social, economic, or scientific life of the people. Under such cirIn

cumstances special investigation and profound research are difficult, and, in
most cases, I may say, impossible. Libraries are small; the hours of school
service in the university are long; the requirements for outside lectures are
great, so that while a Western professor may be able to do some fairly good
work in his attempt to add to the "sum of human knowledge," his chief work
is that of instructor both within and without the university.
The great West is absorbing. In the attempt to develop its resources millions of capital are taken up, much of it never to be returned. It is so in educational affairs. The university and the community demand the professor's
time, his ideas, indeed, his whole life. They take all he has to give just as a
sponge takes water, except that they never reach a point of saturation. I have
this therefore to say of the Johns Hopkins men in the West, that, while probably few of them will put on record any great literary or scientific achievements,
their services will be best noted in the general improvement of the communitks
in which they live and the advancement of the educational institution to which
they are attached.
Under such circumstances it would be impossible to make any definite
estimate of their services in the cause of education or their influences upon
humanity, for much that they do will be shown in the higher educational ideals
and a better social and political life of the community, to be revealed more
especially in the future than in the present, a general good which is traced to
no one in particular.
As it is, the professor in wealthy Eastern institutions, called upon for a
few lectures each week, surrounded by magnificent libraries and finely equipped
laboratories, with comfortable salaries, in close touch with learned societies and
easy access of European learning, may establish lines of culture, write learned
books giving forth new discoveries; but the Western professor must be content
to serve his community though it absorbs his very life, counting it fortunate to
read the results of the research of his more favored brethren in the East, and
conscious that his services are exhibited in the youth he h As helped forward and
the community he has served.

FRANK W. BLACKMAR,

N the dawn of December 26, the members of the Musical Clubs, rubbing
their eyes and joking about being up so early in the morning, left Camden
Station on a special car for West Virginia. Their first concert was given
that night at Charlestown. While the whole programme was well appreciated,
the banjo solo by V. B. Smith, and "Dixie" by the Glee Club, were most
loudly applauded. After the concert, the men were invited to several small entertainments given to them by some of the residents of the town.
When the clubs were on the point of leaving Charlestown the next morning,
a great excitement arose. "Where is Ham, Jr.?" Sure enough the club's
mascot had suddenly disappeared. After considerable searching, he was found,
with his mouth wide open with astonishment, gazing at the "funny" eggshaped heads of the local "crowd."
The second concert was at Winchester, which has always been noted for
the kind reception that she gives Hopkins boys. This year, an audience, even
larger than that of last year, turned out to hear them in the theatre of the new
town hall, built by Charles Broadway Rouss. If the success of the concert could
be measured by the applause, it was immense. The dance given to the club
after the concert by the youth and beauty of Winchester was greatly enjoyed.
The next morning the men hired vehicles, and took their lady friends out driving. But, alas, 2.10 came too soon, and the hard-hearted manager hurried them
off to Hagerstown. Many and touching were the good-byes on leaving Winchester, and the men all declared that it was the place where they wanted to go

EADING aloud is a graceful accomplishment possessed by comparatively
few. Too often the home reading is Fpoiled by a dreary monotone that
the reader does not strive to overcome. If the patient listeners would
only strive to overcome the possesser of the dreary monotone the fault might,
in time, be remedied. How much brighter would home become if we took care

the stockmarket reports if only his silvery-tongued daughter would read the
records to him. In time a great improvement and growth would be seen in the
family (not in size hut in interest.) Little Johnnie would no longer take
pleasure in reading about Diamond Dick in the woodshed; coming under the
benign influence of the home reading circle he would gradually be elevated until he could read with pleasure, if not with profit, the Fables of George Ade, and
the war poems of Rudyard Kipling.
DIRECTIONS: Grab the book, paper, or pamphlet, in the left hand, hold it
to the side, slightly below the face, and about eighteen inches from the head.

naturally. By naturally I do not mean that the elocutionary tyro should shout
Hamlet's Address to the Players, nor declaim in funeral tones the Charge of
the Light Brigade. The neophyte in the realms of oratorical art should strive
to acquire a becoming elocution through carefully, painstakingly, laboriously
